children.value: This is my anylisis of the bildboard top 100 using Pandas, Plotly, Matplotlib in juypter notebook and uploaded into MyST

# Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px
from IPython.display import display
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the data
file_path = 'data.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(file_path)
This is picking out Ed Sheeran individually and analysing his songs over the course of his billdboard hot 100

# Display the first few rows of the DataFrame
display(df.head())

children.value:
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(filtered_data['date'], filtered_data['rank'])
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()  # Invert y-axis as lower ranks are better
plt.title('Ranking of "Bad Habits" by Ed Sheeran Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Billboard Rank')
plt.show()

# Find the top artist
top_artist_counts = df[df['rank'] == 1]['artist'].value_counts()
top_artist = top_artist_counts.idxmax()

# Filter the dataset for the top artist's entries
top_artist_df = df[df['artist'] == top_artist]

# Display the top artist and relevant information
print(f"Top Artist: {top_artist}")
print(top_artist_df[['song', 'peak_rank', 'weeks_on_chart']].head(5))
print("\n")

# Find the top song
top_song_counts = df[df['rank'] == 1]['song'].value_counts()
top_song = top_song_counts.idxmax()

# Filter the dataset for the top song's entries
top_song_df = df[df['song'] == top_song]

# Display the top song and relevant information
print(f"Top Song: {top_song}")
print(top_song_df[['artist', 'peak_rank', 'weeks_on_chart']].head(5))

children.value: “Distribution of Song Longevity” refers to the representation of how long songs remain on a chart. The associated histogram visually displays the categorization of songs based on the number of weeks they occupy on the chart. In this context, each bar within the histogram signifies a specific range of weeks, with the height of the bar indicating the number of songs falling within that particular duration. For instance, a taller bar suggests a greater number of songs within the corresponding time frame. Analyzing the chart involves focusing on the tallest bars, representing the most common durations for songs on the chart. If there is a peak, such as around 8 weeks, it indicates that many songs typically endure for approximately 8 weeks on the chart. For clarification, if a bar at “10 weeks” has a height of 20, it signifies that 20 songs in the dataset spent between 10 and 11 weeks on the chart."

# Song Longevity
fig_longevity = px.histogram(df, x='weeks_on_chart', title='Distribution of Song Longevity')
fig_longevity.show()
